## What you'll learn:
- **Ecosystem Structure** - Biotic and abiotic factors
- **Energy Flow** - Food chains and webs
- **Nutrient Cycles** - Carbon, nitrogen, water
- **Population Ecology** - Growth and dynamics
- **Biodiversity** - Conservation and human impact

> ğŸ’¡ **Fun Fact:** The word "ecology" comes from Greek "oikos" meaning "house" - literally the study of nature's household!

slides.title: Ecosystems
slides.content:
# Ecosystems ğŸŒ³

An ecosystem includes all living organisms AND their physical environment interacting as a system.

## Components

### Biotic Factors (Living)

| Type | Role | Examples |
|------|------|----------|
| Producers | Make own food | Plants, algae |
| Consumers | Eat other organisms | Animals, fungi |
| Decomposers | Break down dead matter | Bacteria, fungi |

### Abiotic Factors (Non-living)

| Factor | Examples |
|--------|----------|
| Climate | Temperature, precipitation |
| Light | Sunlight intensity |
| Soil | Nutrients, pH |
| Water | Salinity, availability |
| Gases | Oâ‚‚, COâ‚‚ concentration |

## Niche vs Habitat

| Niche | Habitat |
|-------|--------|
| Organism's "job" | Where it lives |
| Role in ecosystem | Physical location |
| What it does | Its address |

## Types of Ecosystems

### Terrestrial
- Forest, grassland, desert, tundra

### Aquatic

| Freshwater | Marine |
|------------|--------|
| Lakes, rivers | Oceans, coral reefs |
| Low salt | High salt |
| Ponds, streams | Estuaries |

## Ecosystem Services

- Clean air and water
- Climate regulation
- Pollination
- Food production
- Medicine

> ğŸ¯ **Key Point:** Everything in an ecosystem is connected!

slides.title: Energy Flow
slides.content:
# Energy Flow ğŸ”‹

Energy moves through ecosystems in ONE direction: Sun â†’ Producers â†’ Consumers â†’ Decomposers

## Food Chain

```
Sun â†’ Grass â†’ Rabbit â†’ Fox â†’ Decomposers
      Producer  Primary  Secondary
               Consumer  Consumer
```

## Trophic Levels

| Level | Name | Examples |
|-------|------|----------|
| 1 | Producers | Plants, algae |
| 2 | Primary consumers | Herbivores |
| 3 | Secondary consumers | Carnivores |
| 4 | Tertiary consumers | Top predators |

## Food Web

Interconnected food chains in an ecosystem.

More realistic than a single chain!

## 10% Rule

> Only ~10% of energy transfers to the next trophic level.

```
Sun: 1,000,000 J â†’ Plants: 10,000 J (1%)

             Plants: 10,000 J
                    â†“ 10%
         Herbivores: 1,000 J
                    â†“ 10%
         Carnivores: 100 J
                    â†“ 10%
    Top predators: 10 J
```

## Energy Pyramids

```
       /\     Top predators
      /  \
     /    \   Carnivores
    /      \
   /        \ Herbivores
  /          \
 /____________\ Producers (most energy)
```

## What Happens to the 90%?

- Respiration (heat)
- Waste products
- Uneaten parts
- Decomposition

> ğŸ’¡ **Key Point:** Energy is LOST at each level â€“ that's why there are fewer top predators!

slides.title: Nitrogen Cycle
slides.content:
# The Nitrogen Cycle ğŸ”„

78% of atmosphere is Nâ‚‚, but organisms can't use it directly!

## The Problem

Nâ‚‚ gas has a triple bond â†’ Very stable â†’ Not usable by most organisms

## Nitrogen Cycle Steps

```
    Atmosphere (Nâ‚‚)
         â†“ Nitrogen fixation
    NHâ‚ƒ/NHâ‚„âº (Ammonia/Ammonium)
         â†“ Nitrification
    NOâ‚‚â» â†’ NOâ‚ƒâ» (Nitrate)
         â†“ Assimilation
    Plants â†’ Animals
         â†“ Decomposition
    NHâ‚ƒ (back to ammonia)
         â†“ Denitrification
    Nâ‚‚ (back to atmosphere)
```

## Key Processes

| Process | What Happens | Who Does It |
|---------|--------------|-------------|
| **Nitrogen fixation** | Nâ‚‚ â†’ NHâ‚ƒ | Bacteria, lightning |
| **Nitrification** | NHâ‚ƒ â†’ NOâ‚ƒâ» | Nitrifying bacteria |
| **Assimilation** | NOâ‚ƒâ» â†’ organic | Plants |
| **Ammonification** | Organic â†’ NHâ‚ƒ | Decomposers |
| **Denitrification** | NOâ‚ƒâ» â†’ Nâ‚‚ | Denitrifying bacteria |

## Nitrogen-Fixing Bacteria

### Free-living
- Azotobacter in soil

### Symbiotic
- Rhizobium in legume root nodules

## Human Impact

| Activity | Effect |
|----------|--------|
| Fertilizers | Excess nitrogen |
| Burning fossil fuels | Nâ‚‚O emissions |
| Sewage | Nitrogen pollution |

## Eutrophication

Excess nitrogen/phosphorus â†’ Algal bloom â†’ Oxygen depletion â†’ Dead zones

> ğŸ’¡ **Key Point:** Bacteria are essential for recycling nitrogen!

# Population Ecology ğŸ“Š

Studying factors that affect population size.

## Population Characteristics

| Characteristic | Definition |
|----------------|------------|
| Size | Number of individuals |
| Density | Individuals per area |
| Distribution | How spread out |
| Growth rate | Change over time |

## Distribution Patterns

## Population Growth

### Logistic Growth (S-curve)

```
N â”‚    â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â• K (Carrying capacity)
```

slides.title: Species Interactions
slides.content:
# Species Interactions ğŸ¤

How organisms affect each other.

## Types of Interactions

| Interaction | Species 1 | Species 2 | Example |
|-------------|-----------|-----------|--------|
| **Predation** | + | - | Lion eats zebra |
| **Competition** | - | - | Plants competing for light |
| **Mutualism** | + | + | Bee and flower |
| **Commensalism** | + | 0 | Barnacles on whale |
| **Parasitism** | + | - | Tick and dog |

## Competition

### Interspecific (between species)
- Competitive exclusion: One wins, one goes
- Resource partitioning: Species divide resources

### Intraspecific (within species)
- Competition for mates, territory, food

## Predator-Prey Dynamics

```
     Prey â”€â”€â”€
           \  /
            \/
            /\
           /  \
 Predators â”€â”€â”€â”€

(Populations oscillate, predators lag behind prey)
```

## Symbiosis

Living in close association.

### Examples

| Type | Example |
|------|--------|
| Mutualism | Mycorrhizae (fungi + plant roots) |
| Commensalism | Remora on shark |
| Parasitism | Tapeworm in intestine |

## Keystone Species

Species that has disproportionate effect on ecosystem.

**Example:** Sea otters eat sea urchins
- Without otters â†’ Urchins overgraze kelp
- Kelp forest ecosystem collapses

> ğŸ’¡ **Key Point:** Removing one species can affect the entire ecosystem!

slides.title: Biodiversity
slides.content:
# Biodiversity ğŸ¦‹

The variety of life at all levels.

## Types of Biodiversity

| Type | Definition | Example |
|------|------------|--------|
| **Genetic** | Variation within species | Different corn varieties |
| **Species** | Number of species | Rainforest vs desert |
| **Ecosystem** | Variety of habitats | Forest + wetland + grassland |

## Biodiversity Hotspots

Areas with high species diversity AND high threat.

| Hotspot | Location | Notable Species |
|---------|----------|----------------|
| Madagascar | Africa | Lemurs |
| Amazon | South America | Countless species |
| Coral Triangle | SE Asia | Marine life |
| Western Ghats | India | Amphibians |

## Why Biodiversity Matters

- ğŸŒ¿ Ecosystem stability
- ğŸ’Š Medicine sources (25% drugs from plants)
- ğŸ Food security
- ğŸ¨ Cultural/aesthetic value
- ğŸ”¬ Scientific discovery

## Threats to Biodiversity

**HIPPO:**
- **H**abitat destruction
- **I**nvasive species
- **P**ollution
- **P**opulation growth
- **O**verexploitation

## Conservation Strategies

| Strategy | Description |
|----------|-------------|
| Protected areas | National parks, reserves |
| Captive breeding | Species recovery programs |
| Seed banks | Preserve plant diversity |
| Habitat restoration | Rewilding |
| Legislation | Endangered Species Act |

## Mass Extinctions

6th mass extinction may be occurring now due to human activity.

> ğŸ¯ **Key Point:** We're losing species 1000Ã— faster than natural background rate!
